blocks.name: rusgrnumwwlkl1
blocks.content: In a k-regular graph, there are k walks (as word) of length 1 starting at each vertex. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 28-Jul-2018.) (Revised by AV, 7-May-2021.)

  elrab(s0, c0, c1, wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c2), wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2))

  syl6bb(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), wa(w0, w1), w3a(w0, wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), w1), wa(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), wa(w0, w1)))
  ibar(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), wa(w0, w1))
  bitr3i(wa(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), wa(w0, w1)), w3a(w0, wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), w1), w3a(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), w0, w1))
  3anass(wceq(cfv(c0, nat0), c2), w0, w1)

thm rusgrnumwwlklem(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(c0, c3, c2), cfv(chash, crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0)))))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c4))

  a1ii(wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(c0, c3, c2), cfv(chash, crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0))))), wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c4)))
  a1ii(wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(c0, c3, c2), cfv(chash, crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0))))), diffsc(s0, c1))
  ovmpt2a(s1, s2, c0, c1, c2, cn0, c3, cfv(chash, crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0))), cfv(chash, crab(s0, co(cv(s2), cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), cv(s1)))))
  fveq2d(chash, crab(s0, co(cv(s2), cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), cv(s1))), crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0)), wa(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2)))

  oveq1(cv(s2), c2, cwwlksn, c4)
  adantr(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2), wb(wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), cv(s1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0)))
  eqeq2(cv(s1), c0, cfv(cv(s0), nat0))
  fvex(chash, crab(s0, co(c2, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c0)))

thm rusgrnumwwlklem(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ0)→(c0[c3]c2)=(# ` { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 }))
  ⊣ c1 =(Vtx ` c4)
  ⊣ c3 =(s1 ∈ c1, s2 ∈ ℕ0 ↦(# ` { s0 ∈(s2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= s1 }))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
  ⊣ d(s0, c4)
  ⊣ d(s1, c0)
  ⊣ d(s1, c1)
  ⊣ d(s1, c2)
  ⊣ d(s1, c4)
  ⊣ d(s2, c0)
  ⊣ d(s2, c1)
  ⊣ d(s2, c2)
  ⊣ d(s2, c4)
} = {
  a1ii(((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ0)→(c0[c3]c2)=(# ` { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 })), c1 =(Vtx ` c4))
  a1ii(((c0 ∈ c1 ∧ c2 ∈ ℕ0)→(c0[c3]c2)=(# ` { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 })), d(s0, c1))
  ovmpt2a(s1, s2, c0, c1, c2, cn0, c3, (# ` { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 }), (# ` { s0 ∈(s2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= s1 }))
  fveq2d(chash, { s0 ∈(s2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= s1 }, { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 }, (s1 = c0 ∧ s2 = c2))
  rabeqbidv(s0, (s2[WWalksN]c4), (c2[WWalksN]c4), (s1 = c0 ∧ s2 = c2), (s0 ` 0)= s1, (s0 ` 0)= c0)
  adantl(s1 = c0, s2 = c2, (s2[WWalksN]c4)=(c2[WWalksN]c4))
  oveq1(s2, c2, cwwlksn, c4)
  adantr(s1 = c0, s2 = c2, ((s0 ` 0)= s1 ↔(s0 ` 0)= c0))
  eqeq2(s1, c0, (s0 ` 0))
  fvex(chash, { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 })
  diff.cn0.s(s1)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, chash, { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 })
  diff.chash.s(s1)
  diff.crab.s(s1, s0, (c2[WWalksN]c4), (s0 ` 0)= c0)
  diff.co.s(s1, c2, cwwlksn, c4)
  diff.cwwlksn.s(s1)
  diff.wceq.s(s1, (s0 ` 0), c0)
  diff.cfv.s(s1, s0, nat0)
  diff.cv.s(s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
  diff.nat0.s(s1)
  diff.cn0.s(s2)
  diff.cfv.s(s2, chash, { s0 ∈(c2[WWalksN]c4)|(s0 ` 0)= c0 })
  diff.chash.s(s2)
  diff.crab.s(s2, s0, (c2[WWalksN]c4), (s0 ` 0)= c0)
  diff.co.s(s2, c2, cwwlksn, c4)
  diff.cwwlksn.s(s2)
  diff.wceq.s(s2, (s0 ` 0), c0)
  diff.cfv.s(s2, s0, nat0)
  diff.cv.s(s2, s0)
  diffss.ex(s2, s0)
  diff.nat0.s(s2)
  diff.co.s(s0, s2, cwwlksn, c4)
  diff.co.s(s0, c2, cwwlksn, c4)
  diff.cwwlksn.s(s0)
  diff.wa.s(s0, s1 = c0, s2 = c2)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, s1, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, s1)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, s2, c2)

}

blocks.name: rusgrnumwwlk
blocks.content: In a ` K `-regular graph, the number of walks of a fixed length ` N ` from a fixed vertex is ` K ` to the power of ` N ` . By definition, ` ( N WWalksN G ) ` is the set of walks (as words) with length ` N ` , and ` ( P L N ) ` is the number of walks with length ` N ` starting at the vertex ` P ` . Because of the ` K `-regularity, a walk can be continued in ` K ` different ways at the end vertex of the walk, and this repeated ` N ` times. This theorem even holds for ` N = 0 ` : in this case, the walk consists of only one vertex ` P ` , so the number of walks of length ` N = 0 ` starting with ` P ` is ` ( K ^ 0 ) = 1 ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 24-Aug-2018.) (Revised by AV, 7-May-2021.)

blocks.name: rusgrnumwlkg
blocks.content: In a k-regular graph, the number of walks of a fixed length n from a fixed vertex is k to the power of n. This theorem corresponds to statement 11 in [Huneke] p. 2: "The total number of walks v(0) v(1) ... v(n-2) from a fixed vertex v = v(0) is k^(n-2) as G is k-regular." This theorem even holds for n=0: then the walk consists of only one vertex v(0), so the number of walks of length n=0 starting with v=v(0) is 1=k^0. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 24-Aug-2018.) (Revised by AV, 7-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 5-Aug-2022.)

blocks.name: clwwlknclwwlkdif
blocks.content: The set ` A ` of walks of length ` N ` starting with a fixed vertex ` V ` and ending not at this vertex is the difference between the set ` C ` of walks of length ` N ` starting with this vertex ` X ` and the set ` B ` of closed walks of length ` N ` anchored at this vertex ` X ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 7-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 16-Mar-2022.)

  -| wceq(c2, co(c5, co(c3, cwwlksnon, c4), c5))
  -| wceq(c1, crab(s0, co(c3, cwwlksn, c4), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c5)))
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
} = {
  eqtri(c0, cdif(c1, c2), crab(s0, co(c3, cwwlksn, c4), wa(wceq(cfv(cv(s0), nat0), c5), wne(cfv(clsw, cv(s0)), c5))))

blocks.name: clwwlknclwwlkdifnum
blocks.content: In a ` K `-regular graph, the size of the set ` A ` of walks of length ` N ` starting with a fixed vertex ` X ` and ending not at this vertex is the difference between ` K ` to the power of ` N ` and the size of the set ` B ` of closed walks of length ` N ` anchored at this vertex ` X ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 7-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 8-Mar-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Mar-2022.)
